discussion.content: D seems correct. Schema triggers are executed only when current_user which performs triggering action is the owner of the trigger, therefore "depending on which user is connected".

comments.content:
Yes D and B correct
c is not correct because its fired not just for an event's application

choices.B: They can include SQL and PL/SQL or calls to Java procedures.
choices.C: They are implicitly fired by an event that must occur within an application.
choices.D: They are implicitly fired when a triggering event occurs, depending on which user is connected.
choices.A: They can invoke only PL/SQL procedures.

comments.content: c_tax_rate constant number(2) := 8.25 will also work // output 8 not 8.2

discussion.content:
Yes, the correct answer is A. Line 2.
Explanation -> It is mandatory to define datatype size with varchar but now with number.
v_job_type varchar2(100) := 'TEMP' will be correct
c_tax_rate constant number := 8.25 will also work // output 8.25
c_tax_rate constant number(1) := 8.25 will also work // output 8
c_tax_rate constant number(2) := 8.25 will also work // output 8.2

questions.question_text: Which statements are true about PL/SQL procedures? (Choose all that apply.)

choices.D: A PL/SQL procedure executing on the Oracle database can call an external procedure or function that is written in a different programming language, such as
choices.B: Reuse of parsed PL/SQL code that becomes available in the shared SQL area of the server avoids the parsing overhead of SQL statements at run time.
choices.A: Users with definer's rights who are granted access to a procedure that updates a table must be granted access to the table itself.
choices.C: Depending on the number of calls, multiple copies of the procedure are loaded into memory for execution by multiple users to speed up performance.

discussion.content:
A, in Definer rights, separate grants on the table is not required.
B, this is a performance feature of the plsql
C. Not multiple copies of procedure, 
Not sure, multiple instances of a single copy invoked for multiple users/sessions.
D. True, can call JAVA procedure etc.

A and D are right
explain why A
When you use Return cluase inside a procedure , the control is transferred to the calling program which calls the procedure.
its like an exite in loops.
it will not return any value.
if you want the procedure to return value you must used OUT parameter.

choices.C: A procedure can be executed as part of a SQL expression or as a PL/SQL statement.
choices.A: A procedure can contain a return statement without a value.
choices.D: A function can contain zero or more parameters that are transferred from the calling environment.
choices.B: A function can return multiple values using a single return clause.
